intro: Silene subadenophora, commonly known as the narrow-leaved catchfly, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, pink to reddish-purple flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in meadows, woodland edges, and disturbed areas. Its leaves are narrow and slightly hairy, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. Silene subadenophora is an important plant in ecological studies due to its role in supporting pollinators and its adaptability to various habitats.
